SIR.Name: vulExists
SIR.Description: A vulnerability exists in the Program on a Host, and it has specific ExploitRange and ExploitConsequence. Program is the full path of the executable that contains the security bug.

SIR.Name: vulExists
SIR.Description: A vulnerability with identification ID exists in the Program on the Host.

SIR.Name: vulProperty
SIR.Description: The exploitable range and consequence of the vulnerability with ID.

SIR.Name: bugHyp
SIR.Description: A hypothetical bug in a Program on the Host which has ExploitRange and ExploitConsequence.

SIR.Name: dependsOn
SIR.Description: A Program on a Host depends on a Library, where the type of Library is also “Program”.

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: principal Prin can execute arbitrary code with privilege UserPriv on machine Host.

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: When a principal is compromised, any machine he has an account on will also be compromised

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Local exploit
SIR.Technique: Exploitation for Client Execution (DT) T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation (NB)

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Remote exploit of a server program (remote privilege escalation)
SIR.Technique: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation (DT) T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application (NB)

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Local privilege escalation
SIR.Technique: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism (DT) Exploitation for Privilege Escalation (DT)

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Remote exploit for a client program (exploit remote client)
SIR.Technique: T1078 - Valid Accounts (NB) T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution (NB) T1204 - User Execution (NB) T1566 - Phishing (NB)

SIR.Name: networkService
SIR.Description: A service program Prog is running on host Host as user User. It is listening on port Port of protocol Protocol.

SIR.Name: setuidProgram
SIR.Description: Prog is a setuid (in a Unix system, a setuid program will have the privilege of the owner when executed) program on host Host. The executable file is owned by User.

SIR.Name: clientProgram
SIR.Description: Prog is a client program that when executed, may open a connection to a server over the network.

SIR.Name: malicious
SIR.Description: principal Prin would attack the network system to gain illegal privilege.

SIR.Name: incompetent
SIR.Description: principal Prin is not careful in using computers and its behavior may be utilized by a malicious attacker.

SIR.Name: accessFile
SIR.Description: principal Prin can Access the files specified by Path on machine Host. execCode implies file access
SIR.Technique: T1005 - Data from Local System (NB) T1003 - OS Credential Dumping (NB)

SIR.Name: accessFile
SIR.Description: principal Prin can access files on a NFS server if the files on the server are mounted at a client and he can access the files on the client side
SIR.Technique: Data from Local System (DT) Building Block (NB)

SIR.Name: accessFile
SIR.Description: principal Prin can access files on a NFS client if the files on the server are mounted at the client and he can access the files on the server side
SIR.Technique: Data from Network Shared Drive (DT) Building Block (NB)

SIR.Name: accessFile
SIR.Description: NFS shell

SIR.Name: localFileProtection
SIR.Description: The User on machine Host can have the specified Access to the file Path.
SIR.Technique: Data from Local System (DT) Building Block (NB)

SIR.Name: localFileProtection
SIR.Technique: Data from Local System (DT) Building Block (NB)

SIR.Name: localFileProtection
SIR.Technique: Data from Local System (DT) Building Block (NB)

SIR.Name: fileAttr
SIR.Description: The UNIX file attribute bits.

SIR.Name: ownerAccessible
SIR.Description: The file Path on Machine Host has Access by its owner

SIR.Name: groupAccessible
SIR.Description: The file Path on Machine Host has Access by group

SIR.Name: worldAccessible
SIR.Description: The file Path on Machine Host has Access by anyone

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Trojan horse installation

SIR.Name: nfsExportInfo
SIR.Description: The configuration on an NFS server - which path is exported to which client machine and under what options.

SIR.Name: nfsUserMap
SIR.Description: Maps a user in an NFS request to a user on the server.

SIR.Name: non_root_user
SIR.Description: Invokes a library function that tells if User id is “root”.

SIR.Name: accessFile
SIR.Description: When a principal accesses files in a portion that is exported to a client machine, he is also, in some sense, “accessing” files on a client that mounted that portion.

SIR.Name: nfsMounted
SIR.Description: provided by the scanner, which specifies that a portion on Server is mounted on a local path of machine Client.

SIR.Name: principalCompromised
SIR.Description: Victim’s credential is compromised by Attacker
SIR.Technique: Exploitation for Credential Access (DT) T1003- OS Credential Dumping (NB) T1558 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets (NB)

SIR.Name: principalCompromised
SIR.Description: Incompetent user

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Once the credential of a principal is compromised, an attacker can compromise accounts of the principal on any machine the attacker has access to.
SIR.Technique: Exploitation for Credential Access (DT) TA1078 - Valid Account (NB)

SIR.Name: canAccessHost
SIR.Description: To use the stolen credential to compromise another host, an attacker needs some access to the machine. Either he can get into the machine as another user and then execute the “su” command, or he is able to access the login service (such as sshd) on the host.

SIR.Name: canAccessHost
SIR.Description: Access a host through a log in service

SIR.Name: logInService
SIR.Description: ssh is a log in service

SIR.Name: hacl
SIR.Description: Machine Source can reach DestPort on machine Destination through Protocol.

SIR.Name: netAccess
SIR.Description: principal Prin can send packets from machine Src to Port on machine Dst through Protocol.

SIR.Name: allow
SIR.Description: Specifies which principal can access what data. Anything not explicitly allowed is prohibited. Principal and Data are symbolic names, which are mapped to concrete entities by the binding information.

SIR.Name: hasAccount
SIR.Description: Account is the name of a user account on Host that Principal can access.

SIR.Name: located
SIR.Description: Zone is the network zone Principal may operate from.

SIR.Name: dataBind
SIR.Description: Maps Data to its physical location in the network, Path on Host.

SIR.Name: dataBindDir
SIR.Description: All files under the directory DirPath are bound to Data

SIR.Name: spoofLinkHost5
SIR.Description: ARP Spoofing: an attacker can route the traffic intended for some host to the attacker’s machine. Spoofing the source host in link layer and the impersonated and fooled hosts reside in the same subnet.

SIR.Name: spoofLinkHost
SIR.Description: The impersonated and fooled hosts reside in different subnets.

SIR.Name: spoofLinkHost5
SIR.Description: Attacks on Bus Communication; Principal impersonates as the bus master. The master spoofing scenario: the attacker Principal can log in to the AttackerHost (represented by the localAccess) which is connected to the same bus as FooledHost (represented by the l2Connection). By exploiting a vulnerability in the communication protocol used by ImpersonatesHost and FooledHost (represented by the vulLinkProtocol), Principal is able to impersonate as ImpersonatesHost, which is the master in the bus (isMaster).

SIR.Name: spoofLinkHost5
SIR.Description: Attacks on Bus Communication; Principal impersonates as a bus salve. The slave spoofing scenario: is similar to the master spoofing scenario, except for the fact that ImpersonatesHost is a slave in the bus (represented by the isSlave) and not the master.

SIR.Name: spoofE2EHost7
SIR.Description: DNS Spoofing; NameResolver cache poisoning. The attacker spoofs as the name server and provides malicious binding for legitimate requests. The attacker provides a fake response by utilizing a race condition (i.e., answers faster than the legitimate server).The DNS server communicates using a vulnerable version of the DNS protocol, represented by the isNameResolver and netAccess.

SIR.Name: spoofE2EHost
SIR.Description: The attacker changes DNS records in the name server/host cache. The attacker (Principal) can log in using local access (localAccess predicates) to the DNS server and modify the DNS records to associate the attacker’s host with a naming of his/hers choice. The success of the attack depends on the ability of the fooled host to access the attacker’s host through the network (expressed by the netAccess predicate).

SIR.Name: spoofE2EHost
SIR.Description: Gaining write access permission to some path in the DNS server, which happens to contain a DNS record.

SIR.Name: dos
SIR.Description: Host-based DoS attacks. The attacker Principal (represented by the malicious predicate) exploits his/her login access to Host (represented by localAccess) which runs a vulnerable service that allows DoS (represented by the localService and vulHost).

SIR.Name: dos2
SIR.Description: Vulnerability is exploited via network. Network-based DoS attacks. The attacker Principal exploits his/her access to a network service running on DstHost (represented by the netAccess, aclH, and networkService), which contains a vulnerability that enables DoS upon successful exploitation (represented by the vulHost).

SIR.Name: dos2
SIR.Description: Attacks on Bus Communication; Malicious access to the bus. Attacker Principal (represented by the malicious predicate) can utilize his/her local access (i.e., login or ability to execute code) to a device connected to a bus in order to deny service to any other device connected to that bus (represented by the l2Access predicate).

SIR.Name: mitmLink
SIR.Description: MITM attack in the link layer, in which the entire communication between SrcHost and DstHost is routed through the attacker’s host (SpoofingHost);

SIR.Name: relay2
SIR.Description: Derive relay2 from relay5

SIR.Name: relay2
SIR.Description: Source host is also relay host

SIR.Name: relay2
SIR.Description: Destination host is also relay host

SIR.Name: relay2
SIR.Description: Deriving that an AP is a relay to a flow between hosts in the two zones it connects

SIR.Name: mitmE2E
SIR.Description: MITM attack in the end-to-end layer, in which only a specific application layer protocol (represented by the Port and Prot arguments) is routed through the attacker’s host.

SIR.Name: relay5
SIR.Description: relay2 to relay5

SIR.Name: crackAPEncKey2
SIR.Description: WEP Cracking; Utilizing wireless protocol with weak encryption to extract the encryption key of a device. In order to crack WEP’s encryption, (1) the attacker must capture a large amount of legitimate packets transmitted to/from the access point; and (2) the access point must use the vulnerable WEP protocol.

SIR.Name: crackAPEncKey2
SIR.Description: Utilizing wireless protocol with weak encryption to extract the encryption key of a device

SIR.Name: crackAPEncKey3
SIR.Description: An additional vulnerability in several WPA2 implementations that reinstall an all-zero encryption key upon retransmission of 3rd handshake message.

SIR.Name: accessDataFlow3
SIR.Description: By cracking the encryption key, the attacker can eavesdrop on all of the traffic broadcasted by the compromised access point.

SIR.Name: accessDataFlow3
SIR.Description: Viewing traffic by capturing wireless signals via relay - not necessarily plaintext

SIR.Name: accessDataFlow3
SIR.Description: Reading specific wireless link layer communication

SIR.Name: accessDataFlow3
SIR.Description: Viewing traffic by capturing wireless signals - not necessarily plaintext

SIR.Name: isAuthenticated3
SIR.Description: By cracking the encryption key, the attacker can authenticate to the access point.

SIR.Name: accessLinkFlow
SIR.Description: WPA2 Key Reinstallation. (1) The attacker becomes a MITM between the host and the access point (e.g., by channel-based MITM technique); and (2) the attacker prevents the 4th handshake message from reaching the access point, which causes the retransmission of the 3rd message.

SIR.Name: crackPINCode4
SIR.Description: Bluetooth PIN Cracking; Principal got the PIN code of the Bluetooth communication. The attacker Principal (represented by the malicious predicate) can read the messages exchanged by two devices (represented by the accessDataFlow, dataFlow, and flowBind) during their pairing process (represented by the isPairingProcess).

SIR.Name: crackPINCode4
SIR.Description: Principal got the PIN code of the Bluetooth communication

SIR.Name: accessDataFlow3
SIR.Description: Reading bluetooth data flow between two hosts using cracked PIN code. The consequence of this attack is that the attacker acquires the capability to decipher the communication between SrcHost and DstHost.

SIR.Name: localAccess3
SIR.Description: Principal can execute any code

SIR.Name: localAccess3
SIR.Description: Principal has account and can access via network

SIR.Name: netAccess5
SIR.Description: Principal can access from neighber

SIR.Name: accessFile4
SIR.Description: Vulnerability is exploited via network

SIR.Name: l2Access6
SIR.Description: Host access via shared medium

SIR.Name: l2Connection5
SIR.Description: Connectivity within a bus

SIR.Name: l2Connection5
SIR.Description: Wireless connection between an authenticated host and an encrypted AP

SIR.Name: l2Connection5
SIR.Description: Communication between devices on bluetoothRange

SIR.Name: l2Connection5
SIR.Description: Communication between devices using vulnerability

SIR.Name: l2Connection5
SIR.Description: Connectivity within a subnet

SIR.Name: l2Connection5
SIR.Description: Wireless connection between an encrypted AP and authenticated host

SIR.Name: vulHost5
SIR.Description: A software depends on vulLibrary

SIR.Name: vulLinkProtocol6
SIR.Description: Communication between hosts in the same subnet via vulnerable link layer protocol

SIR.Name: vulLinkProtocol6
SIR.Description: Communication between hosts via vulnerable link layer protocol

SIR.Name: vulLinkProtocol6
SIR.Description: Communication between hosts via vulnerable link layer protocol

SIR.Name: aclNW4
SIR.Description: Connectivity inter subnets

SIR.Name: aclNW4
SIR.Description: Connectivity from host to subnet

SIR.Name: aclNW4
SIR.Description: Connectivity from subnet to host

SIR.Name: aclNW4
SIR.Description: connectivity within a subnet

SIR.Name: dataInject4
SIR.Description: Principal can inject any data from local

SIR.Name: execCode3
SIR.Description: Incompetent user execute malicious code included in injected data
SIR.Technique: T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution T1204 - User Execution

SIR.Name: execCode3
SIR.Description: Exploit vulnerability from adjecent

SIR.Name: located3
SIR.Description: Located via AP

SIR.Name: dataFlow2
SIR.Description: dataFlow related to source host

SIR.Name: dataFlow2
SIR.Description: dataFlow related to end host

SIR.Description: One way dataFlow primitive

SIR.Name: dataFlow3
SIR.Description: Two way dataFlow primitive

SIR.Name: dataFlow3
SIR.Description: Two way dataFlow primitive

SIR.Name: netAccess
SIR.Description: Principal can access DstHost from SrcHost using Protocol and Port.

SIR.Name: localAccess
SIR.Description: Principal can login to DstHost as NetworkServiceUser.
SIR.Technique: T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application (NB) T1021 - Remote Services (NB) T1563 - Remote Service Sessions Hijacking (NB) Building Block (DT)

SIR.Name: dataInject
SIR.Description: Principal can inject data to Path2 on DstHost.
SIR.Technique: T1055 - Process injection T1565 - Data Manipulation

SIR.Name: isAdmin
SIR.Description: Account AdminUser on Host has administrator privilege.

SIR.Name: accessFile
SIR.Description: Principal can access data at Path on Host with Access privilege.
SIR.Technique: Data from Local System (DT) Building Block (NB)

SIR.Name: hasAccount
SIR.Description: Principal has the credential of account User2 on Host2.

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Remote exploit of a service program
SIR.Technique: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation External Remote Services (NB)

SIR.Name: gateway
SIR.Description: Represents cross-subnet network access. For a node in one subnet to access a node in different subnet, the associated gateways must have connectivity through a series of hops.

SIR.Name: flowExists
SIR.Description: Represent active traffic flows between two nodes (source and destination) communicating over a specific protocol, port, and associated with some user account.

SIR.Name: netAccess
SIR.Description: The execCode derivation rule requires that an attacker has network access (the canAccessHost rule) to the victim machine. This overloaded definition enables the derivation of canAccessHost.

SIR.Name: principalCompromised

Rule.Name: // Arp spoof works only if the victim and attacker are in the same subnet
// Victim is using standard arp for address resolution
// The standard arpd protocol is vulnerable to spoofing
// The User has an account on a login service on the remote host
// There is an active connection from the host to the remote machine

SIR.Description: If a victim node that is colocated in the same subnet as the attacker is using the ARP service for address resolution, the attacker may redirect and read (or sniff) the victim node’s traffic. These rules enable representation of an attacker node obtaining a victim node’s credentials if the victim node is using ARP and is using a login service on a remote subnet.
SIR.Technique: Man-in-the-Middle Network Sniffing (NB) Steal Application Access Token (NB) Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets (NB)

SIR.Name: principalCompromised

Rule.Name: // The victim has a user account on the remote host
// nrlolsr is misconfigured allowing traffic hijacking
// The User has an account on a login service on the remote host
// There is an active connection from the host to the remote machine

SIR.Description: The principal is compromised if it has an account, an active connection to a login service on a node, and OLSR is misconfigured. Route hijacking does not require the attacker to be located in the victim’s subnet.
SIR.Technique: Man-in-the-Middle Steal Application Access Token (NB) Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets (NB)

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: The two predicates describe attack stages (i.e., remote and local exploits). The predicate deviceOnline(H,Platform) captures the availability of the device H.
SIR.Technique: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation Command and Scripting Interpreter

SIR.Name: hostImpact
SIR.Description: A compromised host will impact the dependent virtual machines.

SIR.Name: serviceImpacted
SIR.Description: A compromised server will impact the dependent service.

SIR.Name: vulExists
SIR.Description: A virtual machine instance inherits the vulnerability from the parent VMI.

SIR.Name: imageVulExists
SIR.Description: A third party VMI could contain a stealthy bridge.

SIR.Description: remoteExploit of a stealthy bridge

SIR.Name: stealthyBridgeExists
SIR.Description: A stealthy bridge could be built between virtual machines co-residing on the same host after one virtual machine is compromised.
SIR.Technique: Exploitation of Remote Services? Remote Services? (DT) Process Injection? (NB)

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: A stealthy bridge could lead to privilege escalation on victim machine.

SIR.Name: canAccessHost
SIR.Description: Access a host through a log-in service by obtaining authentication information through stealthy bridges.

SIR.Description: Leaking information

SIR.Name: instantiate
SIR.Description: The virtual machine vm is located on the hypervisor h.

SIR.Name: own
SIR.Description: The tenant t is the owner of the element X

SIR.Name: isAttachedTo
SIR.Description: The element X is attached to the virtual port vp

SIR.Name: belongTo
SIR.Description: The virtual port vp belongs to the subnet s

SIR.Name: isLinkedTo
SIR.Description: The network n is linked to the subnet s

SIR.Name: contains
SIR.Description: The security group secg contains the security rule secr

SIR.Name: isEnforcedOn
SIR.Description: The security group secg is enforced on the VM vm

SIR.Name: hasIP
SIR.Description: The element X has the IP address IP

SIR.Name: areColocated
SIR.Description: vm1 and vm2 belong to the same hypervisor.

SIR.Name: isInSubnet
SIR.Description: The VM vm is in the (virtual) subnet s

SIR.Name: areRouted
SIR.Description: The subnets s1 and s2 are connected via the (virtual) router r

SIR.Name: areConnected
SIR.Description: The virtual machines x and y are either on the same subnet or on subnets linked by routers, and their security rules allow communication for at least one combination of addresses, ports and protocol.

SIR.Name: fileAcl
SIR.Description: File Access Control List

SIR.Name: owner
SIR.Description: Each group/user/host/alias in Windows is assigned a Security Identified (SID). This is the equivalent of userid in Linux.

SIR.Name: dacl
SIR.Description: Discretionary Access Control List for the file. AceHeadEntry above is one single entry in the Access Control List.

SIR.Name: mulvalCheckAccess
SIR.Description: No ACL implies no protection. If a file does not have an Access Control List ("Null DACL"), then any access is permitted on the file.

SIR.Name: mulvalCheckAccess
SIR.Description: Owner always gets access. The owner of a file always gets WRITE DAC access to the file. The owner can use the WRITE DAC permission to reset the fle system ACLs. Thus an owner always get access to the file.

SIR.Name: mulvalCheckAccess
SIR.Description: Consult the Access Control List. If none of the previous rules apply, then consult the access control list. Each Access Control Entry(ACE) in the DACL is examined from first to last looking for an entry that denies or allows the action. If the end of the list is reached without a matching ACE, the request is denied.

SIR.Name: checkAccess
SIR.Description: The adversary having any of the super privileges results in he getting access to any file.

SIR.Name: canAccess
SIR.Description: If Principal belongs to Group, he gets any permission that the group can get.

SIR.Name: canAccess
SIR.Description: if Principal has the WRITE DAC ("write discretionary access-control list") permission on the resource, they can make any OtherPrincipal have any Permission on the resource.

SIR.Name: compromised
SIR.Description: If you have been compromised by the attacker, and your account can change the service configuration of a Service to run the attacker's .EXE file in a process owned by Principal, then you can compromise that Principal.

SIR.Name: compromised
SIR.Description: If you can write to a file that some Principal can execute, then you can install a Trojan Horse that makes that Principal act on your behalf.

SIR.Name: checkACE
SIR.Description: An elementary access control decision, using the access control entry AceEntry, for a request Access by a principal whose list of security identifiers of the groups in the process token is SidsList, is Result (one of allowed, denied).

SIR.Name: checkAccessList

Rule.Name: % An empty access control list denies access

SIR.Description: Models the algorithm the kernel uses to decide whether an access control list Acl allows or denies Access to a principal with SidsList as the list of security identifiers of the groups in the process token. This predicate examines the Acl from first to last and unifies the Result variable to allowed or denied accordingly. If there is no access control on the object, then the request is granted. If the end of the list is reached, then access is denied.

SIR.Name: processToken
SIR.Description: Eencodes the credentials of the process requesting the access. UserSid is the user identity on behalf of whom the process runs, Privileges is the set of privileges the process holds, Groups is the set of groups the user belongs to and RestrictedGroups is the set of restricted groups the user belongs to.

SIR.Name: windowsAccessCheck
SIR.Description: Models the algorithm the kernel uses in determining whether to permit an RequestedAccess access to an object with protection ObjectProtection by a process with token RequestingToken. The variable Result is instantiated to allowed or denied accordingly.

SIR.Name: windowsAccessCheck
SIR.Description: No ACL implies no protection.

SIR.Name: windowsAccessCheck
SIR.Description: SeTakeOwnershipPrivilege privilege gives write-owner access.

SIR.Name: windowsAccessCheck
SIR.Description: Owner always gets access.

SIR.Name: windowsAccessCheck
SIR.Description: Consult the Access Control List.

SIR.Name: windowsAccessCheck
SIR.Description: Everything else is denied.

SIR.Name: userToken
SIR.Description: Principal gets the token Token when he logs in.

SIR.Name: canWrite
SIR.Description: Principal can write the resource of type Type (service, registry, file) identified by Name and with a security descriptor Dacl.

SIR.Name: canWrite
SIR.Description: If the adversary has WRITE DAC or GENERIC WRITE permissions, he can write to the resource.

SIR.Name: canWrite
SIR.Description: If the adversary has WRITE DAC or GENERIC WRITE permissions, he can write to the resource.

SIR.Name: canWrite
SIR.Description: If the adversary has FILE WRITE DATA permission on a file, he could overwrite the file.

SIR.Name: canWrite
SIR.Description: If the adversary has KEY SET VALUE permission on a registry key, he could overwrite the contents of the key.

SIR.Name: canWrite
SIR.Description: If the adversary has SERVICE CHANGE CONFIG permission on a service, he could reconfigure the service.

SIR.Name: trusts
SIR.Description: Principal trusts Resource. If a principal executes code in a file, he trusts the file.

SIR.Name: trusts
SIR.Description: Since any one who can configure a service can get administrative access to a machine indirectly, an administrator should trust any service resource.

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: If a principal Target trusts a resource(Type, Name, Dacl) and if a principal Attacker can write to this resource, then the adversary Attacker can launch a privilege escalation to Target.

SIR.Name: dependsOn
SIR.Description: Transitive dependencies

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Local attack against a privileged program

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: Adversary obtains certain privileges on a host and then replaces legitimate programs with a Trojan-horse version. When a user executes such programs, the attacker obtains the privileges of the user.

SIR.Name: nfsMounted
SIR.Description: if an administrative account is compromised on the client side, then the attacker can mount any files.

SIR.Name: accessFile
SIR.Description: If files are mounted on the client side using the NFS protocol, and if the adversary can access files on the client side, then the adversary can access the files on the server side.
SIR.Technique: Data from Network Shared Drive (DT) Derived Environment Rule (NB)

SIR.Name: access
SIR.Description: All possible data accesses that can result from multistage, multi-host attacks

SIR.Name: policyViolation
SIR.Description: Policy checking

SIR.Name: allows
SIR.Description: Apache first consults its filters to determine whether the request made by the client is allowed or not. If yes, apache either serves a request for a path by invoking an operation on the file system of the machine on which it is installed (the first rule), or it forwards the request to one of the modules installed on it (the second rule).

SIR.Name: triggers
SIR.Description: States the conditions under which a request from apache to tomcat is triggered by a request from a client to apache.

SIR.Name: netAccess
SIR.Description: If an attacker can execute arbitrary code on machine H1 at some permission level, and machine H1 can reach machine H2 through Protocol and Port, then the attacker can access machine H2 through Protocol and Port. In this way, privileges on H1 can enable an attacker to access H2.

SIR.Name: netAccess
SIR.Description: advances predicate should return true only when the transition H1 -> H2 is useful.

SIR.Name: cost
SIR.Description: Assign cost values to various configuration conditions and attacker privileges.

SIR.Name: process
SIR.Description: Covering the multiple possible ways that system components might interact during system operation.

SIR.Name: execCode
SIR.Description: An attacker can gain the ability to execute arbitrary code on a Process if he can do so on Process2, the two processors are connected by memory mapping, and Process2 can access the mapped memory range.

SIR.Name: isCompromised
SIR.Description: An internal component is compromised if the attacker controls that particular component.

SIR.Name: isCompromised
SIR.Description: An internal component is compromised if there exists a transitive relationship so that an already compromised component comp1 can invoke a vulnerable method of that component. For instance the frontend component in the running example can exploit an authentication bypass vulnerability in the login method to compromise the account manager, which then enables compromising the database manager via the executeQuery method.

SIR.Name: exCompromised
SIR.Description: An external component can be compromised if it exports an external interface that contains a vulnerability.

SIR.Name: exCompromised
SIR.Description: An external component can be compromised if it can be invoked from a compromised internal component in a method that can cause an external vulnerability, and that vulnerability is present in the external component.

SIR.Name: canInjectCommand
SIR.Description: Command injection attack, enabled by external components.

SIR.Name: canInjectCommand
SIR.Description: Command injection attack, enabled by internal components.

SIR.Name: canPrivEsc
SIR.Description: Command injection and privilege escalation

SIR.Name: canDeleteDoc
SIR.Description: Document deletion
